item.content:encoded:
IP Address:

It’s in general a name assign to a computer, address of a computer. It serves two principles: Host and Network. The Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) manages the IP address globally to local internet registries (Internet Service Providers). The designers of IP Address defined it as a 32 Bit number, and this system is called Internet Protocol Version 4. There are four sessions. Each session contain 8 Bits.  It’s in the numeric format ex: 0.0.0.0 To 255.255.255.255

MIN To MAX

The min range is from 0 to 255 in all the four sessions.

IP Versions:

Two versions of Internet protocols (IP) are in use IP version 4 and IP version 6. Each IP versions define there IP address differently. IPv6 are used but, IPv4 is more preferred in India today.

IPv4 Address:

It’s and address consisting of 32 bit which limit the address space to 255. IPv4 reserves some address for Private networks and Public networks. IP version 4 are represented in dot decimal notation, which consists of four decimal numbers each ranging from 0 – 255, separated by dots. Each part represents a group of 8 bits.

Sub netting:

IP addresses are divided in two parts: Network – Host. Most significant eight bits in an address is called network number and the remaining bits were called host networks within the network. The classes (A B C) were defined for universal addressing. The following table gives an overview of the classes in IP address.

Classes defined.

CLASS A CLASS B CLASS C
0 – 127 128 – 191 192 – 223

Private IP in each class

CLASS A CLASS B CLASS C
10.0.0.0 TO 10.255.255.255 172.16.0.0 TO 172.31.255.255 192.168.0.0 TO 192.168.255.255

IP Address (Networks – Hosts)

CLASS A CLASS B CLASS C
N+H+H+H N+N+H+H N+N+N+H

Private Address

As the IP Address needs to be unique, end to end connectivity was envisioned for communication with internet hosts. However it was not necessary as private networks developed and public address space needs to be conserved. Computer does not connect to internet, such as factory machines connect through TCP/IP which does not need to unique.

By – Gurjeet Kaur.
